title: 111_hr3901
content: The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" enhances the administration of the first-time homebuyer tax credit. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" amends the age limitation for the tax credit, requiring taxpayers to be at least 18 years old at the time of purchasing a residence. Additionally, documentation requirements are updated under this Act. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" updates documentation requirements for claiming the first-time homebuyer tax credit, including penalties for failing to attach a settlement statement to the tax return. Married individuals acquiring a residence from the family of their spouse are also subject to restrictions under this Act. The amendments made by the "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" require documentation to claim the first-time homebuyer tax credit, with penalties for non-compliance. The Act also imposes restrictions on married individuals acquiring a residence from their spouse's family. The amendments made by subsection (b) apply to returns for taxable years after the enactment of the Act, while the amendments made by subsection (d) apply to returns for taxable years after April 9, 2008. Certain tax return preparers are required to file returns electronically. Certain tax return preparers are required to file individual income tax returns on magnetic media if they are specified tax return preparers for the calendar year and expect to file more than 100 returns. The amendment requires tax return preparers to file individual income tax returns electronically if they expect to file 100 or fewer returns in a calendar year. The effective date for this change is after December 31, 2010.
